metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI

defendants.name: E1 ENTERTAINMENT TELEVISION, LLC AND ANR.

key_issues: Here are the main legal issues extracted from the document:
• Whether a rectification petition seeking to cancel a trademark registration can be filed after initiation of a civil suit for infringement?
• Maintenance of a rectification petition when the petitioner was aware of the trademark registration prior to initiating the suit.
• Applicability of Supreme Court judgments (Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors.) in similar cases.
• Section 124 read with Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999: framing a preliminary issue in the civil suit before filing a rectification application.
• Whether the trademark registration in question is in issue in the ongoing civil suit (CS(COMM) 253/2019).
• Applicability of Coordinate Bench judgments (Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr.).
• Whether the petitioner can seek injunction against the respondents using trademarks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW" in the civil suit.
• The scope of relief available for rectification of trademark registration under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
• Whether the respondent's delay in filing a rectification petition is pertinent to its maintainability.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary:**

This is a civil case filed by Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited against E! Entertainment Television, LLC and another company, seeking rectification of the trademark register qua trademark registration no. 1252812 in class 99 (classes 38 and 41). The respondent's registration had been granted on December 2, 2003.

**Background:**

The petitioner, Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited, filed a suit, CS(COMM) 253/2019, against the respondent, E! Entertainment Television, LLC, on May 10, 2019, claiming proprietary rights over trademarks "NOW" and its formative marks, including "ENOW". However, the petitioner has only sought injunctions against the respondent using the trademarks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW", but not questioning the validity of the respondent's trademark registration.

**Legal Issues:**

The main legal issue in this case is whether the petitioner can file a rectification application under Section 124(1) read with Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, despite not having raised the issue of invalidity of the respondent's trademark registration in the earlier suit. The petitioner's counsel argued that since the impugned trademark registration is not in issue in CS(COMM) 253/2019, the judgments relied upon by the respondent are not applicable in this case.

**Arguments:**

1. The respondent's counsel submitted that the petitioner was aware of the respondent's trademark registration as far back as June 6, 2018, and despite filing a suit on May 10, 2019, did not raise the issue of invalidity of the registration.
2. The respondent's counsel relied upon the judgments in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors., (2018) 2 SCC 112, and Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr., (2021) 88 PTC 610, to argue that the present rectification petition is not maintainable.
3. The petitioner's counsel countered by arguing that since the impugned trademark registration was not in issue in CS(COMM) 253/2019, no preliminary issue could be framed under Section 124 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.

**Court Findings:**

The court noted that:

*   The Supreme Court had held in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors., (2018) 2 SCC 112, that a rectification application under Section 38 of the Trade Marks Act, 1950, was not maintainable where the ground for rectification was already pending consideration in another suit between the same parties.
*   Similarly, in Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr., (2021) 88 PTC 610, a Coordinate Bench of this Court held that a preliminary issue could not be framed to consider the invalidity of the respondent's trademark registration.

**Decision:**

The court, relying on the judgments in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels Limited and Ors., (2018) 2 SCC 112, and Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & Anr., (2021) 88 PTC 610, held that:

*   The present rectification petition filed by the petitioner is not maintainable under Section 124(1) read with section 28(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
*   Since the impugned trademark registration was not in issue in CS(COMM) 253/2019 and a preliminary issue could not have been framed to consider its validity.

--- PAGE 1 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 1 of 8 
 
* 
IN  THE  HIGH  COURT  OF  DELHI  AT  NEW  DELHI 
 
% 
 
 
 
                Date of decision: 28th November, 2022. 
 
+  
 
 
 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022  
 
 
BENNETT, COLEMAN AND COMPANY  
LIMITED  
 
 
 
 
 
..... Petitioner 
Through: 
Mr.Hemant Singh, Mrs.Mamta Rani 
Jha 
and 
Mr.Amitesh 
Mishra, 
Advocates. 
 
 
 
 
versus 
 
 
E1 ENTERTAINMENT TELEVISION, LLC AND  
ANR.  
 
 
 
 
 
 
..... Respondents 
Through: 
Ms.Shwetasree Majumder, Mr.Prithvi 
Singh 
and 
Ms.Devyani 
Nath, 
Advocates. 
 
Ms.Anushkaa Arora, Mr.Sahaj Garg, 
Senior Panel Counsels (UOI) and 
Mr.Aditya Sharan, Advocates for R-2 
 
CORAM: 
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral) 
 
I.A. 4831/2022(of the respondent no.1 u/s 151 of CPC) 
1. 
The present rectification petition has been filed on behalf of the 
petitioner for rectification of the trademark register qua trademark 
registration no.1252812, which is registered in class 99 (classes 38 and 41) 
in favour of the respondent no.1 since 2nd December, 2003.   
2. 
The present application has been filed on behalf of the respondent 
no.1 seeking dismissal of the aforesaid rectification petition.  
3. 
Notice in this application was issued on 5th March, 2022 and reply has 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 2 of 8 
 
been filed on behalf of the respondent no.1. Rejoinder thereto has also been 
filed on behalf of the respondent no.1.  
4. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 submits that the petitioner was aware 
of the registration in favour of the respondent no.1 as far back as on 6th June, 
2018 and despite a suit, being CS(COMM) 253/2019, having been filed by 
the petitioner against the respondent no.1 on 10th May, 2019, the petitioner 
took no steps to have a preliminary issue framed on the alleged invalidity of 
the respondent no.1’s trademark. Therefore, in view of the judgment of the 
Supreme Court in Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Anr. v. P.M. Diesels 
Limited and Ors., (2018) 2 SCC 112, followed by a Coordinate Bench of 
this Court in Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd. v. Phonepe Private Limited & 
Anr., (2021) 88 PTC 610, the present rectification petition filed on behalf of 
the petitioner is not maintainable.  
5. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 has placed reliance on the pleadings 
in the aforesaid suit to submit that the mark in respect of which rectification 
is sought by the petitioner herein, was subject matter of the aforesaid suit. 
Therefore, in terms of Section 124 read with Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade 
Marks Act, 1999, a preliminary issue would be required to be framed in the 
aforesaid suit before a rectification application can be filed.  
6. 
Per contra, the counsel for the petitioner submits that the impugned 
trademark registration, which is the subject matter of the rectification 
petition, is not in issue in CS(COMM) 253/2019. In the said suit, the 
petitioner has claimed proprietary rights over the trademark “NOW” and 
“NOW” formative marks including “ENOW”.  Reference is this regard has 
been 
made 
to 
paragraphs 
19, 
20 
and 
21 
of 
the 
plaint 
in 
CS(COMM)253/2019. Hence, the petitioner herein has sought injunction 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 3 of 8 
 
against the respondent no.1 using the trademarks “E! NOW” and “E! NEWS 
NOW”. Therefore, it is submitted that the judgments relied upon by the 
respondent no.1 are not applicable in the facts of the present case. 
7. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
8. 
Section 30(2)(e) and Section 124(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 are 
set out hereunder:  
―30. Limits on effect of registered trade  mark. –  
 2… A registered trade mark is not infringed where— 
(e) 
the use of a registered trade mark, being one of two or more 
trade marks registered under this Act which are identical or nearly 
resemble each other, in exercise of the right to the use of that trade 
mark given by registration under this Act.‖ 
… 
―124. Stay of proceedings where the validity of registration of the 
trade mark is questioned, etc.— 
(1) Where in any suit for infringement of a trade mark— 
(a) the defendant pleads that registration of the plaintiff‘s trade mark 
is invalid; or 
(b) the defendant raises a defence under clause (e) of sub-section (2) 
of section 30 and the plaintiff pleads the invalidity of registration of 
the defendant’s trade mark,  
the court trying the suit (hereinafter referred to as the court), shall,— 
(i) if any proceedings for rectification of the register in relation to the 
plaintiff‘s or defendant‘s trade mark are pending before the Registrar 
or the Appellate Board, stay the suit pending the final disposal of such 
proceedings; 
(ii) if no such proceedings are pending and the court is satisfied that 
the plea regarding the invalidity of the registration of the plaintiff’s 
or defendant’s trade mark is prima facie tenable, raise an issue 
regarding the same and adjourn the case for a period of three 
months from the date of the framing of the issue in order to enable 
the party concerned to apply to the Appellate Board for rectification 
of the register.‖ 
 
9. 
To appreciate the rival submissions, a reference may be made to the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 4 of 8 
 
relevant paragraphs of the plaint in CS(COMM) 253/2019: 
―3. 
That the alleged usage of the marks ‗E! NOW‘ and ‗E News 
NOW‘ is a spurious and malafide besides being an afterthought done 
simply to defeat the rights vested by the Plaintiff in using the mark 
and Logo of ‗NOW‘. 
4… 
(iv) 
That on 10.10.2018, the Defendant Company filed the evidence 
in support of opposition under Rule 45 in Trade mark Application No. 
3679905 and for the first time claimed its right over the mark E! 
NEWS NOW only and not E Now.‖ 
 
10. 
From a reading of the plaint as a whole it emerges that the cause of 
action for filing the aforesaid suit by the petitioner herein was on account of 
respondent no.1 ascertaining rights over the marks “E! NOW” and “E 
NEWS NOW”. In the prayer clause, a decree of permanent injunction is 
sought against the respondent no.1 herein from using the channel/domain 
“E! NOW” and “E! NEWS NOW”, which is deceptively similar to 
petitioner’s mark “E NOW”. There is no pleading in the plaint with regard 
to the mark “
/E!”  and no injunction has been sought against the said 
mark. Therefore, the mark “
/E!” is the not the subject matter of the 
aforesaid suit. 
11. 
In the written statement filed on behalf of the respondent no.1 herein 
in the aforesaid suit, the respondent no.1 has pleaded the registration of the 
mark “
/E!”, which is the subject matter of the present rectification 
petition. However, the aforesaid pleading in the written statement has not 
been raised as a defence to the cause of action pleaded in the plaint in the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 5 of 8 
 
aforesaid suit. In view of the aforesaid pleading made in the written 
statement filed on behalf of the respondent no.1 herein, the petitioner herein 
has rebutted the same in its replication. Merely because the respondent no.1 
herein has pleaded in its written statement the fact of registration being 
granted in its favour in respect of the mark “
/E!”, would not expand the 
scope of the aforesaid suit. Admittedly, the respondent no.1 has not filed any 
suit seeking to restrain the petitioner herein from using the said mark. 
12. 
A reading of the written statement filed on behalf of the respondent 
no.1 herein in the aforesaid suit shows that no defence has been raised by the 
respondent no.1 herein in terms of Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The respondent no.1 has not pleaded that the registered marks of the 
plaintiff are identical to the mark “
 /E!” or nearly resemble each other. 
Therefore, Section 124 (1) (b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 is not attracted 
in the present case. It is not the case of the respondent no.1 that the provision 
of Section 124 (1) (a) is attracted in the present case. 
13. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 has relied upon paragraphs 31 and 32 
of the judgment in Patel Field Marshal Agencies (supra). The same are set 
out below: 
―31.  Rather, from the résumé of the provisions of the 1958 Act made 
above, it becomes clear that all questions with regard to the validity 
of a trade mark is required to be decided by the Registrar or the High 
Court under the 1958 Act or by the Registrar or the IPAB under the 
1999 Act and not by the civil court. The civil court, in fact, is not 
empowered by the Act to decide the said question. Furthermore, the 
Act mandates that the decisions rendered by the prescribed statutory 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 6 of 8 
 
authority [Registrar/High Court (now IPAB)] will bind the civil court. 
At the same time, the Act (both old and new) goes on to provide a 
different procedure to govern the exercise of the same jurisdiction in 
two different situations. In a case where the issue of invalidity is 
raised or arises independent of a suit, the prescribed statutory 
authority will be the sole authority to deal with the matter. However, 
in a situation where a suit is pending (whether instituted before or 
after the filing of a rectification application) the exercise of 
jurisdiction by the prescribed statutory authority is contingent on a 
finding of the civil court as regards the prima facie tenability of the 
plea of invalidity. 
32.  
Conversely, in a situation where the civil court does not find a 
triable issue on the plea of invalidity the remedy of an aggrieved party 
would not be to move under Sections 46/56 of the 1958 Act but to 
challenge the order of the civil court in appeal. This would be 
necessary to avoid multiple proceedings on the same issue and 
resultant conflict of decisions.‖ 
 
14. 
In the aforesaid judgment, relied upon by the respondent no.1, the 
defendants had contested the validity of the plaintiffs’ trade mark “Field 
Marshal” in their written statement and claimed that the same was liable to 
be rectified by the Trademark Registry. Similarly, in Resilient Innovations 
Pvt. Ltd. (supra), in the written statement filed on behalf of the petitioner 
therein (the defendant in the suit between the parties), it was pleaded that the 
registration in favour of the plaintiff therein was invalid. Therefore, the 
aforesaid cases were covered under Section 124 (1) (a) of the Trade Marks 
Act, 1999, which is not the case of the respondent no.1 here. Hence, the 
aforesaid judgments would not come to the aid of the respondent no.1.  
15. 
In my considered view, the mark “
/E!”, which is the subject 
matter of the present rectification petition, is not the subject matter of 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 7 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 7 of 8 
 
CS(COMM)253/2019. In fact, the cause of action for filing the present 
rectification petition was on account of the petitioner coming to know that 
the respondent no.1 has claimed exclusive proprietary rights over the mark 
“
/E!”, when the respondent no.1 issued notices of opposition on 11th 
April, 2018 against the petitioner’s applications for registration of its 
trademarks.   
16. 
In view of the aforesaid discussion, Section 124 of the Trademarks 
Act, 1999 would not apply in the present case. There is no merit in the 
present application and the same is dismissed. 
I.A. 4832/2022 (of the respondent no.1 seeking extension of time to file 
counter statement/reply) 
 
17. 
 The present application has been filed on behalf of the respondent 
no.1 seeking permission to file counter statement/reply after the issue of 
non-admissibility of the present rectification petition as pleaded in I.A. 
4831/2022 is decided.  
18. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 submits that the present application 
has been filed bonafide before 60 days period for filing the counter 
statement/reply had expired. 
19. 
Counsel for the petitioner opposes the present application. He submits 
that the present application has been filed in a malafide manner, only to 
delay the proceedings in the present rectification petition. 
20. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties.   
21. 
In the facts and circumstances of the case, the respondent no.1 is 
permitted to file its counter statement/reply within four weeks from today 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 8 ---
                                    2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 8 of 8 
 
subject to payment of costs of Rs.50,000/- to the petitioner. 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022 
22. 
In view of the directions above, counter statement/reply be filed by 
the respondent no.1 within four weeks from today.  
23. 
Rejoinder thereto, if any, be filed within four weeks thereafter. 
24. 
List before the Joint Registrar for completion of pleadings on 02nd 
February, 2023. 
25. 
List before Court on 15th March, 2023. 
 
 
AMIT BANSAL, J 
NOVEMBER 28, 2022 
dk 
 
 
 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Case Header and Parties
tree_structure.summary:
Here is a summary of the legal document section from PDF:

**Case Header and Parties**

* Case No: 2022/DHC/005230
* Date of Decision: 28th November, 2022
* Parties:
	+ Petitioner: Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited (through Mr. Hemant Singh, Mrs. Mamta Rani Jha, and Mr. Amitesh Mishra)
	+ Respondents: E1 Entertainment Television LLC and Anr. (through Ms. Shwetasree Majumder, Mr. Prithvi Singh, and Ms. Devyani Nath)

**Background**

* Rectification petition filed by Bennett Coleman to rectify trademark registration no. 1252812 in favor of respondent no. 1.
* Respondent no. 1 seeks dismissal of the petition.

**Arguments**

* Counsel for respondent no. 1 argues that petitioner was aware of the registration since June 2018 and should have framed a preliminary issue on alleged invalidity in a previous suit (CS(COMM) 253/2019).
* Counsel relies on Supreme Court judgments to argue that the present rectification petition is not maintainable.
* Counsel for petitioner argues that the impugned trademark registration is not in issue in the previous suit and therefore, the rectification application can be filed.

**Decision**

The matter was decided by Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal (Oral). The court will frame issues in due course of time.

**Source**: Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf

**Proceedings**

* A rectification petition was filed on behalf of the petitioner to remove a trademark registration No. 1252812.
* The respondent sought dismissal of the rectification petition.

The decision is yet to be provided in the given snippet, but it can be inferred that the court was considering the rectification petition filed by the petitioner.

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary**

The case pertains to a trademark dispute between Bennett Coleman and Company Limited (petitioner) and E1 (respondent no.1). The dispute is ongoing in CS(COMM) 253/2019, a civil suit initiated by the petitioner.

**Background and Facts:**

* In 2020, E1 claimed rights over the marks "E! NOW" and "E NEWS NOW" in its opposition to trade mark application No. 3679905.
* The petitioner claims deceptively similar usage of these marks, seeking a permanent injunction against their use.
* There is no pleading about the mark "/E!" in the plaint.

**Arguments:**

* Respondent E1 pleaded registration of the mark "/E!" in its written statement but did not raise it as a defense to the cause of action in CS(COMM) 253/2019.
* The petitioner submits that judgments relied upon by respondent no.1 are not applicable due to the distinct facts of this case.

**Section 30(2)(e) and Section 124(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999:**

* These sections refer to limits on the effect of registered trademarks and the stay of proceedings where the validity of registration is questioned.

**Case Status:**

* The case was considered by the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi on November 28, 2022 (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022).
* The court has framed issues regarding the prima facie tenability of E1's plea about the invalidity of Bennett Coleman's trade mark.

**Source:** Section from PDF file "9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf".

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 3 from the PDF:

**Case Details:** C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022
**Reference Number:** 2022/DHC/005230

**Key Points:**

* The petitioner Bennett, Coleman and Company Limited argues against the respondent no.1 using trademarks "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW".
* The court is referred to Section 30(2)(e) and Section 124(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999.
* Section 124(1) outlines when a suit for infringement can be stayed if the validity of registration is questioned.

**Relevant Statutes:**

* Section 30(2)(e): Registered trade mark not infringed where use is one of identical or nearly resembling trademarks registered under the Act.
* Section 124(1): Stay of proceedings where validity of registration is questioned, including rectification of register before the Registrar or Appellate Board.

**PDF Source:** 9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf

2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 3 of 8 
 
against the respondent no.1 using the trademarks “E! NOW” and “E! NEWS 
NOW”. Therefore, it is submitted that the judgments relied upon by the 
respondent no.1 are not applicable in the facts of the present case. 
7. 
I have heard the counsels for the parties. 
8. 
Section 30(2)(e) and Section 124(1) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 are 
set out hereunder:  
―30. Limits on effect of registered trade  mark. –  
 2… A registered trade mark is not infringed where— 
(e) 
the use of a registered trade mark, being one of two or more 
trade marks registered under this Act which are identical or nearly 
resemble each other, in exercise of the right to the use of that trade 
mark given by registration under this Act.‖ 
… 
―124. Stay of proceedings where the validity of registration of the 
trade mark is questioned, etc.— 
(1) Where in any suit for infringement of a trade mark— 
(a) the defendant pleads that registration of the plaintiff‘s trade mark 
is invalid; or 
(b) the defendant raises a defence under clause (e) of sub-section (2) 
of section 30 and the plaintiff pleads the invalidity of registration of 
the defendant’s trade mark,  
the court trying the suit (hereinafter referred to as the court), shall,— 
(i) if any proceedings for rectification of the register in relation to the 
plaintiff‘s or defendant‘s trade mark are pending before the Registrar 
or the Appellate Board, stay the suit pending the final disposal of such 
proceedings; 
(ii) if no such proceedings are pending and the court is satisfied that 
the plea regarding the invalidity of the registration of the plaintiff’s 
or defendant’s trade mark is prima facie tenable, raise an issue 
regarding the same and adjourn the case for a period of three 
months from the date of the framing of the issue in order to enable 
the party concerned to apply to the Appellate Board for rectification 
of the register.‖ 
 
9. 
To appreciate the rival submissions, a reference may be made to the 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

Here is a summary of page 4 from the provided PDF:

**Case:** C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022

**Petitioner:** Bennett Coleman and Company Limited

**Respondent No.1:** [Not mentioned]

The court is analyzing the relevant paragraphs from the plaint in CS(COMM) 253/2019.

Key excerpts:

* The respondent No.1 claimed its right over the mark "E! NEWS NOW" on 10.10.2018, for the first time.
* The plaintiff's cause of action was based on the respondent ascertaining rights over the marks "E! NOW" and "E NEWS NOW".
* The plaint sought a decree of permanent injunction against using the channel/domain "E! NOW" and "E! NEWS NOW", which is deceptively similar to the petitioner's mark "E NOW".

**PDF Source:** 9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf

2022/DHC/005230

That the alleged usage of the marks ‗E! NOW‘ and ‗E News 
NOW‘ is a spurious and malafide besides being an afterthought done 
simply to defeat the rights vested by the Plaintiff in using the mark 
and Logo of ‗NOW‘.

That on 10.10.2018, the Defendant Company filed the evidence

10. 
From a reading of the plaint as a whole it emerges that the cause of

NEWS NOW”. In the prayer clause, a decree of permanent injunction is

“E! NOW” and “E! NEWS NOW”, which is deceptively similar to

to the mark “
/E!”  and no injunction has been sought against the said 
mark. Therefore, the mark “
/E!” is the not the subject matter of the 
aforesaid suit.

petition. However, the aforesaid pleading in the written statement has not 
been raised as a defence to the cause of action pleaded in the plaint in the

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
Here's a summary of the legal document section from Bennett Coleman vs E1.pdf:

**Case Details**

* Case: Bennet Coleman & Co. Limited v/s Unknown Respondent (2022/DHC/005230)
* Date: November 28, 2022
* Court: Delhi High Court

**Arguments and Facts**

* Petitioner (Bennett Coleman) claims that the respondent's mark " E!" is identical to their registered mark.
* Respondent failed to plead under Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, which would allow them to raise a defense.
* Respondent did not file a separate suit seeking to restrain Bennett Coleman from using the mark.

**Section 124 (1) (b) Not Applicable**

* The court notes that Section 124 (1) (b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 is not attracted in this case as respondent has not pleaded that the registered marks are identical or nearly resemble each other.

**Comparison to Relevant Judgments**

* Counsel for respondent relied on Patel Field Marshal Agencies and Resilient Innovations Pvt. Ltd., but these cases were found to be distinguishable from the present case.

**Decision**

* The court held that respondent's failure to plead under Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 and their non-filing of a separate suit renders them liable for costs.

(Note: This summary is kept under 300 words as per your request. Please let me know if you need any further clarification or details.)

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 5 from the provided PDF (9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf):

**Case Details**

Court: High Court of Delhi
Case Number: 2022/DHC/005230
Suit Number: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022

**Summary**

The petitioner, Bennett Coleman and Company Limited, has filed a reply to the written statement of respondent no.1, which pleaded that the registration of the mark "E!" was granted in their favor. The petitioner rejected this claim, stating that it does not expand the scope of the suit.

**Key Points**

* Respondent no.1 has not filed any suit to restrain the petitioner from using the said mark.
* No defense has been raised under Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 by respondent no.1.
* Section 124 (1) (b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 is not attracted in the present case.

**PDF Source**: 9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 5 of 8 
 
aforesaid suit. In view of the aforesaid pleading made in the written 
statement filed on behalf of the respondent no.1 herein, the petitioner herein 
has rebutted the same in its replication. Merely because the respondent no.1 
herein has pleaded in its written statement the fact of registration being 
granted in its favour in respect of the mark “
/E!”, would not expand the 
scope of the aforesaid suit. Admittedly, the respondent no.1 has not filed any 
suit seeking to restrain the petitioner herein from using the said mark. 
12. 
A reading of the written statement filed on behalf of the respondent 
no.1 herein in the aforesaid suit shows that no defence has been raised by the 
respondent no.1 herein in terms of Section 30(2)(e) of the Trade Marks Act, 
1999. The respondent no.1 has not pleaded that the registered marks of the 
plaintiff are identical to the mark “
 /E!” or nearly resemble each other. 
Therefore, Section 124 (1) (b) of the Trade Marks Act, 1999 is not attracted 
in the present case. It is not the case of the respondent no.1 that the provision 
of Section 124 (1) (a) is attracted in the present case. 
13. 
Counsel for the respondent no.1 has relied upon paragraphs 31 and 32 
of the judgment in Patel Field Marshal Agencies (supra). The same are set 
out below: 
―31.  Rather, from the résumé of the provisions of the 1958 Act made 
above, it becomes clear that all questions with regard to the validity 
of a trade mark is required to be decided by the Registrar or the High 
Court under the 1958 Act or by the Registrar or the IPAB under the 
1999 Act and not by the civil court. The civil court, in fact, is not 
empowered by the Act to decide the said question. Furthermore, the 
Act mandates that the decisions rendered by the prescribed statutory 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL

nodes.title: Page 6
nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 6 from the PDF "9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf":

The court discusses the jurisdiction of the civil court versus the Trade Marks Registry in cases involving invalid trade marks. According to Section 46/56 of the 1958 Act, the registry's decision does not bind a civil court.

In a situation where the issue of invalidity is raised or arises independently of a suit, the registry has sole authority to deal with the matter. However, if a suit is pending, the registry's jurisdiction is contingent on a finding by the civil court regarding the prima facie tenability of the plea of invalidity.

The court refers to a judgment where defendants contested the validity of a trade mark in their written statement and moved for rectification before the registry. However, this case is distinguished from the respondent's situation, which does not involve a plea of invalidity raised in a suit.

Source: 2022/DHC/005230 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022
nodes.content:
2022/DHC/005230 
C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022                                                                 Page 6 of 8 
 
authority [Registrar/High Court (now IPAB)] will bind the civil court. 
At the same time, the Act (both old and new) goes on to provide a 
different procedure to govern the exercise of the same jurisdiction in 
two different situations. In a case where the issue of invalidity is 
raised or arises independent of a suit, the prescribed statutory 
authority will be the sole authority to deal with the matter. However, 
in a situation where a suit is pending (whether instituted before or 
after the filing of a rectification application) the exercise of 
jurisdiction by the prescribed statutory authority is contingent on a 
finding of the civil court as regards the prima facie tenability of the 
plea of invalidity. 
32.  
Conversely, in a situation where the civil court does not find a 
triable issue on the plea of invalidity the remedy of an aggrieved party 
would not be to move under Sections 46/56 of the 1958 Act but to 
challenge the order of the civil court in appeal. This would be 
necessary to avoid multiple proceedings on the same issue and 
resultant conflict of decisions.‖ 
 
14. 
In the aforesaid judgment, relied upon by the respondent no.1, the 
defendants had contested the validity of the plaintiffs’ trade mark “Field 
Marshal” in their written statement and claimed that the same was liable to 
be rectified by the Trademark Registry. Similarly, in Resilient Innovations 
Pvt. Ltd. (supra), in the written statement filed on behalf of the petitioner 
therein (the defendant in the suit between the parties), it was pleaded that the 
registration in favour of the plaintiff therein was invalid. Therefore, the 
aforesaid cases were covered under Section 124 (1) (a) of the Trade Marks 
Act, 1999, which is not the case of the respondent no.1 here. Hence, the 
aforesaid judgments would not come to the aid of the respondent no.1.  
15. 
In my considered view, the mark “
/E!”, which is the subject 
matter of the present rectification petition, is not the subject matter of 
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:01.12.2022 14:22:17
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Court Decision in Bennett Coleman vs E1**

The summary is based on Section "Court Decision" from PDF: 9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf.

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: 2022/DHC/005230
* Date of Decision: November 28, 2022
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Parties:
	+ Bennett Coleman and Company Limited (Petitioner)
	+ Respondent No.1 (E1)

**Background:**

The petitioner company objected to the respondent's claim of exclusive proprietary rights over the mark "/E!" while filing trademark application. The respondent opposed the petition, leading to various applications.

**Legal Proceedings:**

* Rectification Petition CS(COMM)253/2019 was filed.
* Respondent No.1 (E1) filed an application for extension of time to file a counter statement/reply in I.A. 4832/2022.

**Decisions:**

* Section 124 of the Trademarks Act, 1999 did not apply in this case, and there was no merit in the rectification petition.
* The respondent No.1's application seeking permission to file a counter statement/reply after the issue of non-admissibility of the rectification petition was allowed, subject to payment of costs of Rs.50,000/- to the petitioner.
* Timeline for completion of pleadings:
	+ Counter-statement/reply by Respondent No.1 within four weeks from November 28, 2022
	+ Rejoinder thereto, if any, within four weeks thereafter
	+ List before Joint Registrar on February 2, 2023
	+ List before Court on March 15, 2023

**Significance:**

The case involved disputes over trademark rights and exclusivity. The court examined various provisions under the Trademarks Act, 1999 and made a decision based on the merits of

nodes.title: Page 7
nodes.summary:
Based on page 7 of the PDF "9. Bennet Coleman vs E1.pdf" (2022/DHC/005230 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 243/2022), here is a summary of the relevant legal facts, proceedings, arguments, decisions, dates, names, and amounts:

**Fact**: Respondent no.1 claimed exclusive proprietary rights over the mark "/E!" in notices issued on April 11, 2018.

**Rectification Petition**: The cause of action for filing the present rectification petition was due to petitioner's opposition by respondent no.1.

**Section 124 Trademarks Act, 1999**: Inapplicable in this case.

**Decision**: The present application seeking rectification is dismissed with no merit.

**I.A. 4832/2022**: Respondent no.1 seeks extension of time to file counter statement/reply after the issue of non-admissibility of the present rectification petition is decided.

**Argument**: Counsel for respondent no.1 submits that the application was filed bonafide before the expiration of the 60-day period for filing the counter statement/reply.

/E!”, when the respondent no.1 issued notices of opposition on 11th 
April, 2018 against the petitioner’s applications for registration of its
